entry.title: Deep Dive into SAP CPI Adapters: Synchronous vs Asynchronous Communication Patterns
entry.content:
Introduction

As integration technologies continue to grow, SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) plays a pivotal role in enabling seamless connectivity between different systems. It serves as a powerful middleware that enables seamless data exchange between SAP and SAP systems or between SAP and non-SAP systems. One of the core components that make this integration possible is the adapter framework, which defines how messages are exchanged across different protocols, formats, and applications.

Adapters in CPI act as bridges between the integration layer and external systems. Depending on the business scenario, these adapters can follow either a synchronous or asynchronous communication pattern, influencing how data is sent and received between different systems.

This blog provides a deep technical dive into these communication patterns and explores some of the most widely used synchronous and asynchronous adapters in SAP CPI, along with their meanings, purposes, key features, and real-world examples.

Understanding Communication Patterns in SAP CPI

Synchronous Communication

In a synchronous communication pattern, the sender sends a request to the receiver system and waits for a direct response before proceeding further. This pattern is suitable for real-time transactions or interactive systems that require immediate confirmation or data retrieval. It is best for urgent matters, as it allows for immediate feedback.
Typical use cases include API integrations, data validation requests, or real-time service calls.

Example: An HTTP API call from a mobile app to CPI to fetch customer details instantly.

Asynchronous Communication

In asynchronous communication, the sender and receiver are loosely coupled ‚Äî the sender sends the message to the receiver system but doesn‚Äôt wait for an immediate response from it. Messages are usually queued or processed later, allowing higher flexibility and scalability. This communication is more flexible, giving participants time to respond thoughtfully.
This pattern is ideal for batch processing, file-based data transfers, or event-driven systems.

Example: Uploading a file to an SFTP server where CPI processes the data in the background.

Synchronous Adapters in SAP CPI

1. HTTP Adapter

Definition

The HTTP Adapter in SAP CPI facilitates communication using the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). It is one of the most commonly used adapters that allows CPI to connect with REST-based APIs, web services, and applications. HTTP is the primary protocol for interbusiness message exchange.  Applications can send messages to a server by sending HTTP POST or HTTP GET requests to a specified HTTP URL.
HTTP Adapter supports various HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE, enabling flexible integration with both SAP and non-SAP systems.
It is required in scenarios where request-response framework is used.

Purpose / Usage

  • To connect CPI with RESTful APIs or web services.
  • For real-time integrations requiring instant acknowledgment.
  • To send and receive data in JSON, XML, or plain text formats.

Key Features

  • Supports both client (sender) and server (receiver) configurations.
  • Compatible with REST APIs and lightweight JSON payloads.
  • Can be used to expose CPI iFlows as HTTP endpoints for external consumption.

Example Use Case Scenario

A mobile app triggers an HTTP POST request to CPI to check product availability in real-time. CPI connects to SAP S/4HANA, retrieves the stock status, and returns it immediately as an HTTP response.

2. OData Adapter

Definition

The OData Adapter in SAP CPI is designed for communication with systems that expose data via OData (Open Data Protocol) ‚Äî a standardized REST-based protocol developed by Microsoft and heavily used in SAP products like SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP C4C. This adapter works with V4 (which is the latest version) and also with previous backward versions V2 and V3. 
OData services provide metadata-driven, resource-oriented access to data entities, allowing CPI to interact with backend systems using structured operations such as query, create, update, and delete (CRUD). This is mostly used for performing task on the data like creating, reading, deleting etc.
It simplifies real-time data exchange and reduces the need for manual API definition, as metadata is auto-generated from the service URL. The REST APIs of this adapter are easy to consume. THE OData metadata enables the formation of client proxies and tools,

Purpose / Usage

  • To integrate with SAP systems that expose OData services.
  • To perform CRUD operations on data entities.
  • Suitable for real-time scenarios involving business data retrieval or updates.

Key Features

  • Automatic entity mapping based on service metadata.
  • Supports OData V2 and V4 protocols.
  • Allows query options like $filter, $expand, $select for precise data retrieval.
  • Compatible with authentication methods like OAuth 2.0, Basic, and Principal Propagation.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow retrieves employee details from SAP SuccessFactors through an OData GET request and returns the structured response to a corporate HR portal instantly.

3. SOAP Adapter

Definition

The SOAP Adapter supports communication through SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) ‚Äî SOAP is an older protocol compared to HTTP/OData, but still widely used in enterprises, especially for secure and structured messaging. The SOAP adapter is used to connect with systems that expose SOAP web services. A SOAP adapter can be configured for either synchronous or asynchronous communication, depending on the requirements of the integration scenario. The choice depends on factors like whether an immediate response is needed and how the system should handle potential delays. 
It is often used in enterprise-grade integrations that require strict adherence to data structure, message validation, and security policies.
The adapter supports WSDL (Web Services Description Language)-based configuration, enabling CPI to easily integrate with legacy systems and services that still rely on SOAP endpoints. This adapter exposes the inbound endpoints for accepting the requests that are addressed to a particular URL. The requests are then passed to the next step in the integration flow as part of the message payload, along with the SOAP headers.

Purpose / Usage

  • To integrate CPI with SOAP-based or WSDL-driven web services.
  • Commonly used where schema validation, security, and transactional reliability are critical.
  • Ideal for synchronous request-response integrations.

Key Features

  • Supports WS-Security for message-level encryption and authentication.
  • Handles large XML payloads efficiently.
  • Provides built-in SOAP fault handling and retry mechanisms.
  • Compatible with both 1.1 and 1.2 SOAP versions.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow sends a SOAP request to an external credit bureau service to perform a customer credit check and receives the score synchronously before proceeding with loan approval.

4. ProcessDirect Adapter

Definition

The ProcessDirect Adapter allows direct, high-performance communication between integration flows within the same tenant in SAP CPI. This is basically use to split a very large integration flow into different smaller integration flows that can further be managed and controlled by different users. This adapter is being used by the developers when they want to boost the performance of their integration flow. Its like one splitted iflow becomes the producer iflow and the other becomes the consumer iflow. So the consumer iflow will consume the message that is being processed and passed by the producer iflow. 
It provides an internal channel for message exchange, eliminating the need for external network transmission.
This adapter is typically used for modular integration design, where a parent iflow can invoke multiple child iflows (subprocesses) synchronously to reuse logic or perform specific tasks.

Purpose / Usage

  • To enable communication between iFlows in the same tenant.
  • For modular design and reuse of business logic.
  • To enhance performance by avoiding HTTP overhead.

Key Features

  • Operates synchronously by default.
  • No additional authentication required since it‚Äôs internal to the tenant.
  • High-performance and low-latency communication.
  • Simplifies maintenance by promoting modularization.

Example Use Case Scenario

In a company, if one iFlow handles ‚Äúemployee onboarding‚Äù and another iFlow handles ‚Äúsending welcome emails,‚Äù So when a new employee will get onboarded then the onboarding iFlow can directly trigger the email iFlow using ProcessDirect without repeating the same logic.

 

Asynchronous Adapters in SAP CPI

1. SFTP Adapter

Definition

The SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol) Adapter is used for file-based data exchange between CPI and external systems via a secure SSH connection. It ensures encrypted, secure transmission of files between systems. SFTP is widely used in batch-oriented integrations, particularly when integrating with legacy systems or business partners who exchange data through flat files such as CSV, XML, or JSON. It ensures end-to-end security during file transfers and supports large data volumes. Using this adapter as a source will allow you to read data from a file as well as fetch a particular file from a directory. Using this adapter as a target will allow you to transfer data to a specified file on the server.

Purpose / Usage

  • For secure file transfers to and from CPI.
  • Common in B2B integrations and scheduled data exchanges.
  • Used in scenarios with delayed or periodic processing.

Key Features

  • Supports both sender and receiver modes.
  • Encryption through SSH keys or passwords.
  • File archiving, deletion, and duplicate handling options.
  • Compatible with large file sizes and different payload formats.

Example Use Case Scenario

Think about a supplier who provides a large retailer with a daily stock availability report. Instead of emailing, the supplier drops a CSV file into a secure SFTP folder. The retailer‚Äôs system picks it up automatically.

2. FTP Adapter

Definition

The FTP (File Transfer Protocol) Adapter enables CPI to exchange files with systems over standard FTP or FTPS (FTP Secure). It transfers files to any public server in either binary or ASCII format. FTP is similar to SFTP but less secure because it doesn‚Äôt encrypt data. It‚Äôs still used in many organizations for bulk file transfers where security is not the highest priority. This adapter supports streaming for transferring very large data files. It also supports host key authentication, public key authentication and multilevel authentication.
While similar to SFTP, it uses SSL/TLS-based encryption in FTPS mode or plain transfer in FTP mode. It‚Äôs typically used in internal system communications or non-critical file transfers where performance and simplicity are prioritized over encryption strength.

Purpose / Usage

  • For exchanging data files with internal or external systems.
  • Used for scheduled or bulk data integration scenarios.
  • Common in environments where traditional FTP servers are still used.

Key Features

  • Supports FTP and FTPS modes.
  • Configurable directory paths and file filters.
  • Can read, write, and delete files on remote servers.
  • Lightweight and easy to configure for internal networks.

Example Use Case Scenario

Weather stations upload temperature readings via FTP to a central government database, where data is less sensitive but needs to be transferred quickly and in bulk.

3. Mail Adapter

Definition

The Mail Adapter enables CPI to send or receive emails using SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) for outbound communication and POP3/IMAP for inbound processing. The Mail adapter allows integration with email systems like Gmail, Outlook, or corporate mail servers. It can send and receive mails as part of integration flows. It supports attachments and can handle HTML or plain text content, allowing integration scenarios where notifications, alerts, or data files are exchanged through email systems.

Purpose / Usage

  • To send automated email notifications or reports.
  • To process incoming emails with attachments.
  • Used in system-to-human or human-to-system communication flows.

Key Features

  • Supports multiple email protocols (SMTP, IMAP, POP3).
  • Allows custom subject lines, body templates, and attachments.
  • Compatible with secure connections (TLS/SSL).
  • Can poll inboxes periodically for new messages.
  • If a mail server is communicating with the mail adapter, We can configure security settings to encrypt or decrypt the messages.

Example Use Case Scenario

An iFlow automatically sends an email alert with attached error logs to the system administrator whenever a process fails in CPI. Another example can be let's say whenever you order food from Zomato or Swiggy, you immediately get a confirmation email. That‚Äôs an example of system-triggered emails using integration. Or lets say when you book a flight ticket online, you instantly get a confirmation email with your ticket details. That‚Äôs exactly how mail adapters are used to automatically send communication to customers.

4. JMS Adapter

Definition

The JMS (Java Message Service) Adapter enables asynchronous communication using message queues and topics. It ensures reliable, persistent, and decoupled message delivery between systems.
It is particularly useful in large-scale, event-driven integrations where message sequencing, retry logic, and guaranteed delivery are essential. This adapter works well with external JMS applications, Web servers and Java EE applications.

Purpose / Usage

  • To manage queued message exchanges in asynchronous scenarios.
  • To decouple senders and receivers for scalability and resilience.
  • Suitable for load balancing and guaranteed delivery use cases.

Key Features

  • Supports queues and topics for message broadcasting.
  • Provides guaranteed delivery, persistence, and retries.
  • Enables distributed and parallel message consumption.
  • Integrates with other CPI adapters and enterprise message brokers.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow pushes order events into a JMS queue. Another iFlow picks up these messages later to update the SAP backend, ensuring reliable, asynchronous order processing.

 

Conclusion

Choosing between synchronous and asynchronous adapters in SAP CPI is not just a technical decision. It‚Äôs a strategic choice that directly impacts the performance and scalability of the integration flows across different systems. Each communication pattern serves a distinct purpose: synchronous adapters like HTTP, OData, SOAP, and ProcessDirect enable request‚Äìresponse integrations, ideal for scenarios requiring instant acknowledgment or data retrieval. On the other hand, asynchronous adapters such as SFTP, FTP, Mail, and JMS ensure flexibility in high-volume, event-driven, or batch-oriented integrations.

A well-designed integration architecture in SAP CPI typically leverages a hybrid approach, where both synchronous and asynchronous communications are used .This combination allows organizations to balance performance, fault tolerance, speed and resource optimization effectively.

Furthermore, understanding the strengths and weaknesses of each adapter empowers integration developers to choose the right tool for the right situation. For instance, HTTP adapter is used for sending and receiving data over HTTP protocols and is used mainly for request-response cases. On the other hand, Let's say, We have SFTP adapter which is used for securely transfer files between various systems. Another example, Let's say, We have OData adapter which can be used for integrating SAP systems like SAP S/4HANA or Successfactors, and then we have Mail adapter which allows integration with email systems like Gmail, Outlook or corporate mail servers. So every adapter has its own feature and functionality and thus should be use when a proper situation arises for it.

As enterprises continue to grow and use the cloud-first architectures and systems, the role of adapters in SAP CPI becomes even more crucial. By mastering these adapters and their communication models, integration specialists can build scalable and secure iFlows that support digital transformation goals with agility and confidence. In essence, the right adapter strategy not only streamlines system connectivity but also lays the foundation for an intelligent integration ecosystem within SAP‚Äôs cloud platform.

entry.title: Streamline Your Production with Kanban Control Cycles Analysis
entry.content:
Managing production workflows efficiently requires clear visibility into your kanban processes. The Kanban Control Cycles Analysis app (F5235) provides exactly that ‚Äì a comprehensive tool to monitor and optimize your kanban containers and their status across your entire operations.

What makes this app essential?

This application focuses on the status of circulating kanban containers, helping you spot critical situations before they impact production. Whether you're dealing with error-prone control cycles or excessive empty containers, you'll get early warnings that matter. 

The app starts with high-level insights at the plant level, then allows you to drill down to specific kanban control cycle details. This top-down approach ensures you never miss the forest for the trees.

This is what the app looks like:

The app works on both desktop and tablet devices, ensuring you can monitor your kanban processes wherever your work takes you.

Key features at a glance:

  • Flexible filtering: Analyze your kanban control cycles by plant, material, supplier, or production supply area. This helps you focus on the areas that matter most to your operations.
  • Detailed status tracking: See not just the total number of containers, but also how many are empty, waiting, in transit, or have errors. Percentages help you quickly spot imbalances or bottlenecks.
  • Customizable visualizations: Choose from bar charts, heat maps, and donut charts to visualize your data in the way that best suits your needs.
  • Drill-down capabilities: Start with an overview at the plant level, then drill down to specific control cycles or supply areas for deeper insights.
  • Additional measures and dimensions: Use replenishment-specific fields such as supplier and purchasing organization or measures like control cycle release and lock dates or actual and requested container quantities to evaluate or filter control cycles and container statuses.

 How can you apply the features in practice?

  • To compare container status distributions across different production supply areas, it is helpful to use stacked bar charts.



  • For plant-wide summaries, pie charts work well to show overall container statuses. 

  • When troubleshooting specific materials, it is important to focus on empty containers and containers with errors, aggregated per supply area. You can use predefined app views for this purpose. 

  • To identify control cycles that are no longer needed, use the measure "Days Since Last Container Change". This helps you evaluate when the last status change of a container in this group occurred.

To learn more about the app, check out the documentation on the SAP Help Portal: Kanban Control Cycles Analysis | SAP Help Portal

Conclusion

The Kanban Control Cycles Analysis app is a helpful tool for optimizing your production workflows by providing detailed insights into your kanban processes. With its flexible filtering, detailed status tracking, and customizable visualizations, this app ensures you can efficiently manage your kanban containers and address potential issues before they disrupt production. Whether you're monitoring from a desktop or a tablet, the app's drill-down capabilities allow you to gain both high-level and detailed insights into your operations.

We invite you to explore the app further and share your experiences or any feedback you might have. Feel free to leave your comments or questions below!

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: SAP GTS Edition for SAP HANA 2025, Sneak Preview
entry.content:
Since Christmas is not far away, I think I would grant you your secret wish: get an early preview of what‚Äôs coming in SAP Global Trade Services, edition for SAP HANA 2025.

As per the Product Availability Matrix, this release is planned for this quarter so the Help Portal will be updated accordingly in time, but, if you read this blog, it‚Äôs because Santa‚Äôs helpers ‚Äì here more likely Volker Mohr from Product Management and Torsten Stolz from Engineering, have provided a sneak preview of what you can expect in this release. 

 

Planned enhancements

 

Enablement of the administrator function in SAP Fiori launchpad

A modernization of the user interface for administrators is planned by providing access to transactions using SAP Fiori launchpad. This will help increase work efficiency and enable the administrator role to be consistent with other business roles.

 

Mass maintenance of agreement-specific product properties

This enhancement will enable users to complete the maintenance of agreement-specific properties for one or multiple products at the same time in one screen, hence reducing the administrative burden and increasing information quality at the same time.

 

Maintenance of country and region of origin in inbound LTSD (technical delivery)

First technical delivery in what will further be improved with subsequent Support Packages, the maintenance of country and region of origin will allow users to maintain this information in the inbound Long Term Supplier Declaration (LTSD) at the product level.

 

New SAP Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Partners ‚Äì SPL Screening‚Äù

The previous app ‚ÄúManage Blocked Business Partners‚Äù will be deprecated and a new Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Partners ‚Äì SPL* Screening‚Äù will enable users to process all business partners, whether they are blocked or released.

This ensures that organizations can also manage business partners which were released before and block them again or add them to positive or negative lists.

In this app, the user will be able to easily navigate among screening results of different business partners.

* SPL: Sanctioned Party Lists

 

Updates to screening capabilities of the sanctioned party list

 

The planned enhancement of the screening capabilities of the sanctioned party list will help improve compliance with international regulations and ensure frictionless international trade processes by allowing ‚Äúblock by association‚Äù between a business partner and bank master data.

To achieve this the following capabilities will be added:

  • Transferring SWIFT/bank identifier codes (BICs) and benefit-in-kind (BIK) codes of bank master data from the feeder system to SAP GTS
  • Transferring a relationship between business partners and banks during the transfer of customers, vendors, and employees from the feeder system and storing the relationship in SAP GTS
  • Managing of additional addresses of account holders in the bank details in business partner master data
  • Screening of bank master data with related IDs in SAP GTS
  • Screening of customers and vendors with associated bank

 

Integration with decentralized advanced shipping and receiving processes

 

Integration of SAP Global Trade Services (SAP GTS) with support for the outbound processes of advanced shipping and receiving in a decentralized extended warehouse management and transportation management landscape for trade compliance and customs management will increase efficiency with integration of the decentralized scenario for outbound freight management supported by SAP GTS. This enhancement will include:

  • Compliance check for the outbound freight unit and freight order
  • Export declaration based on the freight order

  

Railway bill of lading 

 

The Customs Waybill for Rail feature ensures compliance with U.S. Customs requirements for rail shipments by accurately transmitting waybill data. The feature addresses complexities in coordinating freight forwarders, carriers, and BOL issuers for rail cargo. Overall, it streamlines rail logistics in the context of SAP GTS processes for Importation and US Free Trade Zone processes with customs authorities.

 

Automated Partnering Government Agency (US PGA) change messaging

 

The CA/CC messages supports the changes of PGA Data of a declaration even after no change to the declaration itself is allowed any longer. The system automatically detects the changed PGA data after being changed in the declaration and transmits these to US CBP.  By this you can ensure to compliantly close all PGA activities even after customs declaration fixation.

 

Modernization of the interface for product transfer

 

A new option to transfer the material master with the Document Replication Framework (DRF) from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Global Trade Services will enable distribute product information, including classification, to SAP GTS.

 

Legal changes

 

And of course, in addition to the functional and technical enhancements, legal changes are also planned.

These can be found in the Regulatory Change Manager which provides timely information on upcoming regulatory changes that can affect SAP products. It offers a comprehensive and well-organized collection of information, and filters by product. To focus only on updates relevant for SAP GTS for instance.

This Regulatory Change Manager service can be accessed directly from the SAP For Me portal, under the Services & Support dashboard in the sidebar.

 

Be the first to know!

 

They say that information is power, so be the first to know about the details of any enhancement in SAP Global Trade Services, edition for HANA via the dedicated SAP Help Portal Page:

What's New in SAP Global Trade Services, edition for SAP HANA | SAP Help Portal

This page consolidates delta information about all functions of this product that are new, changed, or deleted not only for the latest version, but also all previous updates, and will be updated for SAP GTS, edition for SAP HANA 2025 in due time. 

Finally, on December 9th, there will also be an SAP Global Trade Services Latest Release Updates webinar focused on updates on the last shipment, but also Roadmap, Regulatory Changes and a Q&A. You can register here: SAP Global Trade Services Latest Release Updates

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Building Low-code/No-code SAP CPQ extension using SAP Build Process Automation (Part 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP CPQ (Configure Price Quote) is a software solution that allows customers to configure products and services, set up pricing and discounts, generate accurate quotes, and create custom proposals. While offering a great deal of functionality out-of-the-box, SAP CPQ can also be easily extended and customized, to support custom, and often unique, business processes and procedures.

One way in which SAP CPQ can be extended is by developing an external extension application that is integrated with SAP CPQ using standard integration mechanisms (REST APIs, events, webhook notifications etc.). This approach, also known as side-by-side extensibility, has several distinctive benefits: increased flexibility in terms of technological choice, possibility of using dedicated resources, better performance due to limited scope and many more.

This series of blog posts will explore several ways for building and deploying side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ, using the SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and various tools offered by that platform.

  • Building Low-code/No-code SAP CPQ extension using SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1)
  • Building Low-code/No-code SAP CPQ extension using SAP Build Process Automation (Part 2) - this post

Overview of the solution

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code solution that enables you to automate workflow processes without writing a single line of code, just by using a graphical, drag-and-drop editor. It is an ideal solution for developing both simple extensions, as well as complex business process applications. To learn more about SAP Build Process Automation, please check the official documentation.

Overview of the solution (including Part 1 and Part 2)

In the first blog post, we have described how you can invoke SAP Build Process Automation process from SAP CPQ. In this second post, we will demonstrate how to invoke SAP CPQ API from SAP Build Process Automation project using the concept of SAP Build Actions. Actions encapsulate the details of a call to an external API, including the endpoint location, input and output parameters.

For the Action to be able to call, in our case, SAP CPQ API, it needs the information about the location of the SAP CPQ instance, as well as details about the authentication employed (authentication mechanism, credentials, etc.). This information is defined in an SAP BTP Destination, and used in the runtime by the Action when invoking an API.

Example SAP Build Process Automation process used in this blog post series

As an example extension application that we want to integrate with SAP CPQ, we are going to use a simple business process involving legal check of created quotes. The process triggers manual check based on the market associated with the quote, and allows the responsible persons to decide whether quote should be accepted or rejected from the legal perspective. The decision then triggers invocation of appropriate custom CPQ action, something that is described in this blog process.

 

Please note that, in this blog post, I assume that you are familiar with the basics of using SAP Build Process Automation. If that is not the case, please check the excellent "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning.

 

Defining a CPQ Action project in SAP Build

To define a new Action project for invoking SAP CPQ API, navigate your SAP Build Process Automation instance and select SAP Build Lobby -> Connectors -> Actions -> Create.

The easiest way to consume an SAP CPQ API is to use the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, which contains API definitions for many SAP applications, including the SAP CPQ. Select API Specification -> SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Enter the keyword identifying the SAP CPQ API that you want to consume (for example, if you are interested in Quotes API, enter the quote keyword). Select the SAP CPQ API that you want to consume.

Next screen contains the list of actions available in the selected SAP CPQ API. Click Next.

Here, you can customize Action project name and description or use the defaults. Click Create.

In the next screen, you are presented with the list of all available actions in the selected SAP CPQ API. Select the desired actions and click Add.

Before being able to use the selected actions in your SAP Build Process Automation project, you need to release and publish the Action project. First, click on Release button, optionally enter the description and click Release again. After that, select Publish -> Publish.

 

Calling the CPQ API from SAP Build Process Automation project

After publishing the Action project, you can use selected SAP CPQ API actions in your SAP Build Process Automation project, for example, as a new step in the process. To do so, click on the + button (Add Process Step) at the place in the process where you want to invoke an SAP CPQ API.

Then select Action -> Browse All Actions and select the desired action (from previously created and published Action project). Then click Add button.

Next, click on Destination Variable -> Create Destination Variable and specify an Identifier and Description of the variable that will hold a reference to the SAP BTP Destination pointing to your SAP CPQ instance (created and explained later in this blog post). Once you are ready to publish and deploy your SAP Build Process Automaton project, you will associate this variable with the concrete SAP BTP Destination (also explained later). For now, you can specify any value as an Identifier, preferable the one that makes it easy to understand its purpose (for example: CpqDestination). You can reuse the same variable for all the SAP CPQ actions that you use in your project.

Most of the SAP CPQ API actions define a set of input values (required and optional input parameters) and an output value (result of the API call). If the action you are planning to use has the required inputs, you can specify them by selecting the Inputs tab and choosing the input value (for each input) from the list of potential values (for example, an output from one of the previous steps) in the Process Content pane.

You can consume the output of the SAP CPQ API actions in the same way as you would consume output of any other process step in the project: you can display it on the form, use it as input parameter for other actions etc.  In our example, a form is the step in the process that needs the information from the output, so we can use action's output fields as the values of the input fields of that form by selecting them in the Process Content pane (under the Process Inputs section). These fields (and the represented structure of the output) correspond to the response of the call to the related SAP CPQ API endpoint.

 

Before being able to deploy your SAP Build Process Automation project, you first need to define an SAP BTP Destination pointing to the SAP CPQ instance of your choice.

 

Defining a destination in SAP BTP

To connect SAP Build Process Automation instance with an SAP CPQ instance, it is necessary to define a new Destination in the SAP BTP subaccount where the SAP Build Process Automation instance is located. As a first step, a new Trusted Application (OAuth 2.0 client application) in SAP CPQ should be created. To add a new Trusted Application, in the SAP CPQ setup go to Security -> Trusted Applications, then click on Add New -> Add new Trusted Application:

  • Specify a descriptive Name for this trusted application (client)
  • Note the Client ID and Client Secret that you will use in the next step
  • Enable Client Credentials Grant and
  • Specify a (preferably technical) user that will be used when accessing the instance.

It is also possible to use other OAuth 2.0 grant types in this case - for more information, please check SAP CPQ documentation and SAP BTP Connectivity documentation (for example, if you want to use the principle propagation option when accessing the SAP CPQ API, you can use SAML 2.0 assertion grant type, as described in SAP CPQ documentation, SAP BTP Connectivity documentation, and in this blog post). Please note that it is generally recommended to define a separate Trusted Application per client application (application accessing the SAP CPQ API), and to enable only required OAuth grant types.

After configuring Trusted Application in SAP CPQ setup, a new Destination needs to be created in the SAP BTP subaccount where the SAP Build Process Automation instance is located. To do so, go to the subaccount, select Connectivity -> Destinations, and click on Create -> From Scratch -> Create:

  • Specify a descriptive Name for this destination
  • Specify base URL of your SAP CPQ instance
  • Select OAuth2ClientCredentials as an Authentication method (if you enabled Client Credentials Grant in the previous step; if not, please consult the documentation)
  • In the Client ID and Client Secret fields, paste the value generated in the previous step (in the configuration of the Trusted Application in your SAP CPQ instance)
  • Specify Token Service URL by using the base URL of your SAP CPQ instance and adding the /oauth2/token suffix (or consult the documentation)
  • Select Use Basic credentials for Token Service
  • For the Token Service User field, use the same value as for the Client ID field
  • For the Token Service Password field, use the same value as for the Client Secret field

 

Importing destination into SAP Build

After creating Destination in SAP BTP subaccount, it needs to be imported into SAP Build environment. Navigate your SAP Build Process Automation instance, and select SAP Build Lobby -> Control Tower -> Backend Configuration -> Destinations -> Add. Select the Destination you have created in the previous step and click Next.

On the next screen, select the SAP Build environment to which you want to associate new Destination and click Add Destination.

 

Deploying SAP Build Process Automation project

After creating and importing SAP BTP Destination for an SAP CPQ instance, you can deploy your SAP Build Process Automation project on a desired environment (before doing that, please make sure that you have released a version of your project, as described in documentation).

The process of deploying SAP Build Process Automation project is described in detail in official documentation.  What is important to note here is that you will be asked to specify a Destination for the Destination Variable you have previously defined and used for the SAP CPQ API actions. When asked to do so, please select the Destination you have imported in the previous step.

That's it!

Conclusion

In this blog post, we have demonstrated how to build side-by-side extensions of SAP CPQ using SAP Build Process Automation, a low-code/no-code platform that seamlessly integrates with SAP CPQ, and the rest of the SAP ecosystem. Side-by-side extensions can help you in customizing SAP CPQ to support your concrete business processes and requirements. In the following blog posts, we will talk about other SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) tools and services that can help you in developing side-by-side extensions for SAP CPQ.

Resources

  • "Creating Processes and Automations with SAP Build Process Automation" learning journey at SAP Learning
  • API specification

entry.title: Fixing Out-Of-Turn Access in Performance Management for Manager Visibility
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently, while configuring a performance form in SAP SuccessFactors Performance Management, I encountered a situation where the manager couldn‚Äôt open the form even though Out-of-Turn Access (OOTA) had already been granted.

The form was at the Employee Assessment step, and logically, with OOTA enabled, the manager should have been able to access it. However, the system displayed an error message, and I was unable to provide my rating as the manager.

Scenario

- Route Map: Employee Assessment ‚Üí Manager Assessment ‚Üí Calibration ‚Üí Manager Signature ‚Üí Employee Signature
- Performance form is in the Employee Assessment step.
- Out-of-Turn Access is enabled for the Manager (EM) role. This means the manager should be able to open the form in the Employee Assessment step (owned by the employee). In this step, the requirement is that the manager should read employee ratings and provide their own ratings in the Goals and Competency sections.

Problem: When the manager opens the form, they are unable to rate in the Employee Assessment step, even though OOTA is enabled.

Root Cause

Out-of-Turn Access allows a user to open a form outside of their assigned step, but it does not override existing section or field permissions.

In this scenario, the manager role isn‚Äôt part of the Employee Assessment step and therefore has no write or read permissions at that route step. The system treats the manager as having no active context for the form.

Hence, even with OOTA enabled, the form cannot be edited.

In simple terms: OOTA extends access ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt replace permissions.

Resolution Steps

  1. Verify Form, Section, and Field Permissions

Go to Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Templates ‚Üí [Performance Template] ‚Üí Permissions
Ensure the Manager (EM) role has:
- Form-level permission: ‚ÄúRead permission in all steps‚Äù
- All Section permissions: at least Read access
- (Optional) Write access if managers should rate during the employee step

  1. Check Advanced Settings for OOTA

Admin Centre ‚Üí Form Template Settings ‚Üí Advanced Settings
Ensure ‚ÄúAllow users with Out-of-Turn Access to view all sections‚Äù is checked. This allows users with OOTA to open the form even if some sections are read-only.

  1. Review Route Map

In Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Route Maps, confirm that the Manager (EM) role appears at least once in the route. If it doesn‚Äôt, OOTA cannot resolve permissions.

  1. (Optional) Grant Write Access for Ratings

If the manager needs to rate items while the form is in the employee step, change section and field permissions from Read ‚Üí Write for manager rating. This allows the manager to edit ratings even before the form moves to their step from Team Overview.

In this case, the employee can be given rating permission as ‚ÄúUnofficial Rating,‚Äù so it doesn‚Äôt impact the final rating.

Note: If a route map assigns the same role (e.g., Manager) to two separate steps, and both have OOTA enabled, managers can only use OOTA for the first step they encounter. To avoid this limitation, it‚Äôs best not to enable OOTA for roles that appear multiple times in the same route map.

Best Practice

If your business process requires managers to review or comment while the form is still in the Employee Assessment step:
- Keep the manager‚Äôs section permissions as Read
- Enable ‚ÄúView form in all steps‚Äù (e.g., use ‚ÄúDisable‚Äù permission in field permission)
This ensures visibility without unintended edits ‚Äî keeping access logic clean and compliant.

References

- SAP KBA 2088241 ‚Äì Out-of-Turn Access Behavior in Performance Management
- SAP KBA 2088295 ‚Äì Route Map and Permissions Dependencies
- SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Performance Management Implementation Guide: Permissions and Out-of-Turn Access

entry.title: Streamlining Education Document Transfer in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Technical Challenge:

SAP SuccessFactors offers standard integration for education and employment data‚Äîbut only for fields, not attachments. This means that any documents submitted during the recruitment process, do not move to the employee profile upon hiring.

The objective is to have the documents that are verified during background verification, should be part of the employee profile.

What Didn‚Äôt Work: Custom Portlet in Onboarding

One of the options that we thought could help us achieve the objective was creating a custom object in Onboarding and letting the candidate upload the documents there. While creating a custom portlet in Onboarding seemed promising, it had two major flaws:

  • No direct transfer from Job Application to Onboarding: There is no standard solution to move the verified documents from Job Application in Recruiting to Onboarding.
  • User Experience: Asking candidates to upload the required documents in the custom object would not be a good user experience as we are asking to upload same documents twice during the recruitment process.
  • Authenticity and Data Inconsistency: While Candidates re-upload documents, it would increase the risk of data inconsistency and authenticity.

 

What Worked: CPI Integration

We then resolved this issue using SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) to create a secure, scalable, and candidate-friendly solution. It is successfully implemented for a Norway Oil and Natural Gas customer and is working seamlessly.

Here‚Äôs how we did it:

  1. Created custom portlet for education in Employee Profile.
  2. Mirrored fields in the Job Application template.
  3. Enabled document attachments to flow through CPI.
  4. Set permissions to lock document edits post-offer stage.
  5. Triggered integration based on:
    • ‚úÖ Application Status: ‚ÄòHired‚Äô
    • ‚úÖ Background Check: ‚ÄòCompleted‚Äô
    • ‚úÖ Education Data/Documents: ‚ÄòProvided‚Äô

 Field Mapping Snapshot

Field

Job Application

Employee Profile

Degree

custom_EducationDegree

cust_AchievedDegree

Completion Date

custom_EducationDate

cust_CompletedDate

Documents

attachment2

cust_Documents

Key Takeaway

By leveraging SAP CPI, we ensured a frictionless transfer of education documents‚Äîpreserving authenticity, reducing redundancy, and enhancing the overall HR workflow. This has enabled the HR to have verified and automated flow of Education documents from Recruiting process to Employee Profile in EC and at the same time enhancing End User Experience.

entry.title: Automated Budget Calculation for Spot Awards
entry.content:
Employee recognition is evolving rapidly and so the processes to manage it. Among the various recognition methods spot awards has been a powerful tool to motivate employee and celebrate their employee exceptional contribution. however, HR team often face challenges in managing these awards, as manual efforts and fulfilment can be time consuming and prone to errors.

 With SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 release we now have an option to automate our budget calculations for spot awards. This feature helps planner to manage and allocate recognition budget in faster and more efficient way.

What‚Äôs new?

The enhancements allow planners to automatically calculate spot award budgets based on business rules. Instead of manually uploading excel files and budgets,

we can now set up the budget for your Spot Award programs to be calculated automatically by the system.

 The Automated Budget Calculation process includes:

  • Manager Hierarchy: Only standard hierarchies are supported for Automated Budget Calculation.
  • Budget Holders: Can be all managers or a selection based on Dynamic group or a business rule.
  • Budget Allocation: Can be a flat amount, based on a selection of pay components, or on a business rule.

Once the criteria have been met, we can run the draft calculation, preview the system budget, and then choose to finalize or discard these values based on our requirement.

The budget calculation and allocation are managed by jobs within the system, which can be tracked using the Job Monitor. Additionally, we have the option to manually update budgets for budget holders, even when Automated Budget Calculation is enabled.

Configuration Requirements

Go to Reward and Recognition-> Manage Spot Award Programs -> Budget and enable Automated Budget Calculation.

What's Changed

How It Looks Now

In the current version, we can set up criteria and use the system to create budget values for budget holders. The Calculate button is available once the required fields are populated. The Download becomes available once the job to calculate is complete and refreshed the screen for Budget. After we download and review the calculated values, use the Finalize or Discard options to act as desired.

Conclusion: -

Spot awards are a vital part of employee engagement but managing them effectively requires both flexibility and control. With Automated Budget calculations, SAP SuccessFactors compensation empowers HR teams to streamline recognition program, reduce administrative overhead and ensure fairness in budget distribution.

This enhancement is more than a technical upgrade ‚Äì it‚Äôs a step toward making recognition smarted, scalable and sustainable.

entry.title: SAP PPM Configuration: Global Settings, Currency Options and Fiscal Year Variant
entry.content:
Introduction: This Blog Post focuses on Global Settings where consultant can enable / disable the default settings to meet the client specific requirements, Currency Options, how to enable the currency in Portfolio objects and Fiscal Year Variant, where need to be assigned in PPM as well as in Controlling Area.

SAP PPM Configuration:

Topics Covered:

  • Global Settings
  • Currency Options
  • Fiscal Year Variant

Override Default Global Settings: In this customization activity, the default global settings provided by SAP can be modified to align with required values that meet specific business requirements.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Global Settings ‚Äì Override Default Global Settings

Area

Text

Name

Text

Settings Value

Explanation

0006

User Interface Settings

0004

Create Project on Saving Checkbox for Proj. Mgmt <Visible='X' Hidden

X

This will enable / disable  the checkbox option for creation of Project for Project Management (cProject)

0006

User Interface Settings

0005

Proj. Mgmt  Template Visibility <Visible='X' Hidden=' '>

X

This will enable/ disable the Project Management Template

0007

General Default Values

0003

Default Value for Currency

USD

This will enable the default value for currency, say for example you want to enable the INR as default currency in PPM, you should maintain currency as INR

0010

Portfolio Item FI/CO Planning and Integration

0006

Fiscal Year Switch (see SAP Note 1457426)

K4

To display the data in Fiscal Year format, the Fiscal Year variant must be consistent between the Item and the controlling element. This consistency is essential for importing planning data from the Portfolio Item to the controlling object, such as WBS or Internal Order.

0010

Portfolio Item FI/CO Planning and Integration

0007

Default Fiscal year variant (see SAP Note 1457426)

K4

With this setting, the Fiscal Year variant can be automatically defaulted. Since different countries have varying fiscal year periods for financial controlling and data processing, this configuration allows for the appropriate Fiscal Year variant to be set as the default.

 

Currency Option in Bucket:

In the Bucket, under the Financial and Capacity Information tab, you need to select a Currency, as this is a mandatory field by default in SAP. While it can be changed to optional, it is recommended to keep mandatory fields intact at the Bucket level, as they will affect the subsequent associated Initiatives and Items for Financial and Capacity planning.

Regardless of previous settings where you may have maintained a default currency value, such as INR, you will only see two options as default in the Bucket: "United States Dollar" and "European Euro," as illustrated in the screenshot below.

Now, let‚Äôs see what is there in the configuration which is defaulting these currencies in Bucket.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global  Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio-Independent Settings ‚Äì Define Currency Units

We can see here USD and EUR are maintained by default:

Let‚Äôs add INR and then we will see further in Bucket.

Now we can see Indian Rupee option also got enabled in Bucket.

Settings of Fiscal Year Variant in PPM and PS:

The Fiscal Year Variant plays an important role in financial postings and in linking the PPM with the Project System WBS or Internal Order.

Assignment of Fiscal Year Variant in PPM.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio  Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Global Settings ‚Äì Override Default Global Settings

Area

Text

Name

Text

Settings Value

Explanation

0010

Portfolio Item FI/CO Planning and Integration

0006

Fiscal Year Switch (see SAP Note 1457426)

K4

To display the data in Fiscal Year format, the Fiscal Year variant must be consistent between the Item and the controlling element. This consistency is essential for importing planning data from the Portfolio Item to the controlling object, such as WBS or Internal Order.

0010

Portfolio Item FI/CO Planning and Integration

0007

Default Fiscal year variant (see SAP Note 1457426)

K4

With this setting, the Fiscal Year variant can be automatically defaulted. Since different countries have varying fiscal year periods for financial controlling and data processing, this configuration allows for the appropriate Fiscal Year variant to be set as the default.

Fiscal Year Variant in Portfolio Type:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio Dependent Settings ‚Äì Define Portfolio Types

Fiscal Year Variant in SAP Project System:

The Fiscal Year variant for the Project WBS is determined in the background based on the Controlling Areas assigned to the Project. It is important that the controlling area has the same Fiscal Year variant as the one set in PPM.

Transaction Code: OKKP

Validate / maintain the required Fiscal Year Variant in Other Settings section.

Note: If the Fiscal Year variant in the Controlling Area is different from the one configured in PPM, you may receive an error when transferring Planned Costs or Budgets from the PPM Item to the PS Project, indicating that ‚ÄúNo planning element has been assigned to this item‚Äù.

Conclusion:

By reviewing the settings mentioned in this article, you will be able to:

1. Override the default Global Settings provided by SAP, allowing you to enable or disable various functionalities as explained in this article.
2. Enable the necessary currency option at the bucket level for financial planning.
3. Ensure that the same fiscal year variant is maintained in both PPM and the controlling areas used in PS.

SAP Portfolio and Project Management  SAP Portfolio and Project Management for SAP S/4HANA PLM Project System (PS)
